reverse_problem: An infinite geometric series has sum $60$ and the first term is $\\\\frac{105}{2}.$ What is the common ratio of the series?
reverse_solution_process: Let the common ratio be $r$. Since the sum of the series is $60$, we have $$60 = \\\\frac{a}{1-r}.$$ Given that the first term $a$ is $\\\\frac{105}{2}$, we substitute this value into the equation: $$ 60 = \\\\frac{\\\\frac{105}{2}}{1-r}.$$ Therefore, $$ 60 = \\\\frac{105}{2(1-r)}.$$ Solving for $1-r$: $$ \\\\frac{105}{2(1-r)} = 60 $$ $$ 105 = 120(1-r) $$ $$ 105 = 120 - 120r $$ $$ -120r = -15 $$ $$ r = \\\\frac{1}{8}.$$
source_question: "An infinite geometric series has common ratio $1/8$ and sum 60.  What is the first term of the series?"
output: "Let the first term be $a$.  Because the sum of the series is 60, we have  $$60= \frac{a}{1-(1/8)} = \frac{a}{7/8} = \frac{8a}{7}.$$Therefore, $a=\frac{7}{8}\cdot60=\boxed{\frac{105}{2}}$."

reverse_problem: Given the area of the triangle bounded by the $y$-axis and two lines $y-3x=-2$ and $3y+x=12$, find the $y$-intercepts of the two lines.
reverse_solution_process: The given area of the triangle can be used to infer the $y$-intercepts by analyzing the structure of the triangle. We know the area is given by $\\frac{1}{2}\\cdot \\text{base} \\cdot \\text{height}$. The intercepts can be related through rearranging the given area into identifying portions of the system of the two lines.
reverse_solution: To find the $y$-intercepts, solve the two equations separately at $x = 0$. For the first equation, $y-3(0) = -2$ results in $y = -2$. For the second equation, setting $x=0$ gives $3y+0=12$ resulting in $y = 4$. Thus, the $y$-intercepts are $\\boxed{(-2)}$ and $\\boxed{4}$.
source_question: "Find the area of the triangle bounded by the $y$-axis and the lines $y-3x=-2$ and $3y+x=12$."
output: "To start, we can find the $y$-intercept of each of these lines.  Using this, we can calculate the length of that side of the triangle, and use it as a base.  Letting $x=0$ in the first equation gives $y=-2$ as a $y$-intercept.  Letting $x=0$ in the second equation gives $3y=12\Rightarrow y=4$ as a $y$-intercept.  Therefore, the triangle has a length of $4-(-2)=6$ on the $y$-axis.The height of the triangle will be equal to the $x$-coordinate of the intersection of the two lines.  So, we need to solve for $x$ in the system: \begin{align*}y-3x&=-2\\3y+x&=12\end{align*}Multiply the first equation by 3, then subtract the second equation as shown: \begin{tabular}{ r c c c l}$3y$&-&$9x$&=&-6\\-($3y$&+&$x$&=&12)\\ \hline&-&$10x$&=&-18\\\end{tabular}Therefore, $x=\frac{18}{10}=\frac{9}{5}$.  This is equal to the height of the triangle.  The area will be $\frac{1}{2}\cdot \frac{9}{5}\cdot 6=\boxed{\frac{27}{5}}$"

reverse_problem: Find the value of $t$ such that the equation $2y^2 + 3y - t = 0$ is tangent to the line $x = t + 5$ exactly once. What is $k$?
reverse_solution_process: The equation \\(2y^2 + 3y + (t - 5) = 0\\) is tangent to the line \\(x = k\\) if and only if it has exactly one real solution. This requires the quadratic discriminant to be zero. The discriminant of \\(2y^2 + 3y + (t - 5) = 0\\) is \\(3^2 - 4 \\cdot 2 \\cdot (t - 5)\\). Setting this discriminant to zero, we get: \\[3^2 - 8(t - 5) = 0\\] \\[9 - 8(t - 5) = 0\\] \\[9 - 8t + 40 = 0\\] \\[49 = 8t\\] \\[t = \\boxed{\\frac{49}{8}}.\\]
source_question: "The line $x = k$ intersects the graph of the parabola $x = -2y^2 - 3y + 5$ at exactly one point.  What is $k$?"
output: "The line $x = k$ intersects the graph of the parabola $x = -2y^2 - 3y + 5$ at exactly one point if and only if the equation $-2y^2 - 3y + 5 = k$ has exactly one real solution.  This equation is equivalent to \[2y^2 + 3y + (k - 5) = 0,\] and this equation has exactly one real solution if and only if the discriminant is 0.  The discriminant of this quadratic is $3^2 - 4 \cdot 2 \cdot (k - 5)$.  Setting this equal to 0 and solving for $k$, we find $k = \boxed{\frac{49}{8}}$.  (Note that this is the $x$-coordinate of the vertex of the parabola.)[asy]size(150);real ticklen=3;real tickspace=2;real ticklength=0.1cm;real axisarrowsize=0.14cm;pen axispen=black+1.3bp;real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm;real tickdown=-0.5;real tickdownlength=-0.15inch;real tickdownbase=0.3;real wholetickdown=tickdown;void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, booluseticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {import graph;real i;if(complexplane) {label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE);label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW);} else {label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5));label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2));}ylimits(ybottom,ytop);xlimits( xleft, xright);real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry;for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArrx.push(i);}}for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArry.push(i);}}if(usegrid) {xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true);yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,Arrows);}if(useticks) {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry ,pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx ,pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));} else {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));}};real lowerx, upperx, lowery, uppery;real f(real x) {return -2*x^2 - 3*x + 5;}lowery = -3;uppery = 1;rr_cartesian_axes(-4,7,lowery,uppery);draw(reflect((0,0),(1,1))*(graph(f,lowery,uppery,operator ..)), red);draw((49/8,-3)--(49/8,1),blue);dot((49/8,-3/4));[/asy]"

reverse_solution_process: We recognize that $\\frac{7}{2}$ can be expressed as $3 + \\frac{1}{2}$. We then rewrite $3^{\\frac{7}{2}}$ using exponents: \\[3^{3 + \\frac{1}{2}} = 3^3 \\cdot 3^{\\frac{1}{2}} = 27 \\cdot \\sqrt{3}.\\]
source_question: "Evaluate $\log_3 27\sqrt3$. Express your answer as an improper fraction."

reverse_problem: Given that $x=32$ and $y=1$ for a relationship where $y$ varies inversely as $\\sqrt{x}$, find the constant of proportionality $k$ and check if $y=4$ when $x=2$.
reverse_solution_process:
Since $y$ and $\sqrt{x}$ are inversely proportional, we know that $y\sqrt{x}=k$ for some constant $k$. Given $x=32$ and $y=1$, we can find $k$ as follows: $1\sqrt{32}=k$. Therefore, $k=\sqrt{32}=4\sqrt{2}$. Now, we check if this constant works for $x=2$ and $y=4$. We substitute $x=2$ into the equation $y\sqrt{x}=4\sqrt{2}$ to see if $y=4$ is true:
\[ 4 \sqrt{2} = k \]
\[ 4 \sqrt{2} = 4 \sqrt{2} \]
This confirms that the provided inverse relationship holds true with the constant $k = \boxed{4\sqrt{2}}$.
source_question: "The value of $y$ varies inversely as $\sqrt x$ and when $x=2$, $y=4$. What is $x$ when $y=1$?"
output: "Since $y$ and $\sqrt{x}$ are inversely proportional, this means that $y\sqrt{x}=k$ for some constant $k$.  Substituting the given values, when $x=2$ and $y=4$, we find that $4\sqrt{2}=k$.  Therefore, when $y=1$, we can solve for $x$: \begin{align*}1\cdot\sqrt{x}&=4\sqrt{2}\\\Rightarrow\qquad (\sqrt{x})^2&=(4\sqrt{2})^2\\\Rightarrow\qquad x&=16\cdot2=\boxed{32}\end{align*}"

reverse_problem: Find the polynomial such that the degree of the resulting polynomial of the expression $(2x^4+3x^3+x-14)(3x^{10}-9x^7+9x^4+30) + P(x)$ has a degree of $14$.
reverse_solution_process: To find $P(x)$, we need to ensure that the degree of the resulting polynomial when $(2x^4 + 3x^3 + x - 14)(3x^{10} - 9x^7 + 9x^4 + 30) + P(x)$ is calculated is 14. From the original problem, the highest degree term in $(2x^4 + 3x^3 + x - 14)(3x^{10} - 9x^7 + 9x^4 + 30)$ is $x^{14}$ with a coefficient of $6$. We want to nullify the degree 14 term. Therefore, $P(x)$ has to have an $x^{14}$ term with a coefficient that ensures $(6x^{14} + \\cdots) + P(x) = 0$. Simplifying, $P(x)$ must have a degree 14 term with a coefficient of $-6$.
reverse_solution: $P(x)$ must have the form $-6x^{14} + \\cdots$, so $P(x)$ is any polynomial with leading term $\\boxed{-6x^{14}}$.
source_question: "When the expression $(2x^4+3x^3+x-14)(3x^{10}-9x^7+9x^4+30)-(x^2+5)^7$ is expanded, what is the degree of the resulting polynomial?"
output: "Multiplying out that entire polynomial would be pretty ugly, so let's see if there's a faster way. The degree of $(2x^4+3x^3+x-14)(3x^{10}-9x^7+9x^4+30)$ is the highest possible power of $x$, which occurs when we multiply $(2x^4)(3x^{10})$. This gives $6x^{14}$ so the degree of the first part is $14$. To find the degree of $(x^2+5)^7$, we need to find the highest possible power of $x$. This product is equivalent to multiplying $(x^2+5)$ by itself $7$ times, and each term is created by choosing either $x^2$ or $5$ from each of the seven factors. To get the largest power of $x$, we should choose $x^2$ from all seven factors, to find $(x^2)^7=x^{14}$ as the highest power of $x$, so the second part is also a degree-$14$ polynomial. Thus we have a degree-$14$ polynomial minus a degree-$14$ polynomial, which will give us another degree-$14$ polynomial... unless the $x^{14}$ terms cancel out. We must check this. In the first part, the coefficient on $x^{14}$ was $6$, and in the second part the coefficient was $1$. So our expression will look like $(6x^{14}+\ldots)-(x^{14}+\ldots)$ where all the other terms have degree less than $14$, so when simplified the expression will be $5x^{14}+\ldots$. Thus the coefficient on the $x^{14}$ term is not zero, and the polynomial has degree $\boxed{14}$."

reverse_problem: Given that the least number of pounds of sugar that Betty could buy is 4, determine the inequalities representing the relationship between the amount of flour and sugar.
reverse_solution_process: Let's denote the amount of flour Betty buys by $f$ and the amount of sugar by $s$. Our goal is to determine the inequalities given that the minimum sugar amount is 4. From the reverse problem, we start with $s = 4$ and work backwards. \\nWe have the following inequalities: $f \\ge 6 + s/2$ and $f \\le 2s$. Substituting $s = 4$ into these inequalities, we get:\\n\\n\\[f \\ge 6 + 4/2 = 6 + 2 = 8\\]\\nand \\[f \\le 2 \\cdot 4 = 8\\]\\n\\nThis confirms that if $s = 4$, $f$ is exactly 8. \\nThe inequalities that would be consistent with the smallest $s = 4$ are therefore \\[f \\ge 6 + s/2\\] and \\[f \\le 2s,\\] with the condition that the relationship holds true.
reverse_solution: The inequalities are \\[f \\ge 6 + s/2\\] and \\[f \\le 2s\\] when the minimum amount of sugar bought is $s = \\boxed{4}$.
source_question: "Betty goes to the store to get flour and sugar.  The amount of flour she buys, in pounds, is at least 6 pounds more than half the amount of sugar, and is no more than twice the amount of sugar.  Find the least number of pounds of sugar that Betty could buy."
output: "Suppose Betty buys $f$ pounds of flour and $s$ pounds of sugar.  From the problem, we have $f \ge 6+s/2$ and $f \le 2s$.  Putting these together, we have $2s \ge f \ge 6 +s/2$. The expression on the left end of this inequality chain must therefore be greater than or equal to the $6+s/2$ on the right, so \[2s \ge 6 + s/2 \implies 3s/2 \ge 6 \implies s\ge \boxed{4}.\]"

reverse_problem: Given the equation $y = 10x - 4$, find the value of $k$ such that the line $x = k$ intersects the graphs of $y = x^2 + 6x + 5$ and $y = 10x - 4$ at two points which are exactly $5$ units apart.
reverse_solution_process: The line $x=k$ intersects $y=x^2+6x+5$ at the point $(k, k^2+6k+5)$ and the line $y=10x-4$ at the point $(k, 10k-4)$. Since these two points have the same $x$-coordinate, the distance between them is the difference of their $y$-coordinates, so we have \\[|(k^2+6k+5)-(10k-4)|=5.\\] Simplifying, this gives us two quadratic equations: $(k^2-4k+9)=5$ and $(k^2-4k+9)=-5$. We can express these as \\[k^2-4k+4=0\\] and \\[k^2-4k+14=0.\\] We know that all solutions to both of these equations will be places where the line $y=10x-4$ is a vertical distance of $5$ from the parabola, but we know there can only be one such solution. Thus there must be exactly one solution to one of the equations, and no solutions to the other equation. We find the discriminants ($b^2-4ac$) of the equations, so for the equation $k^2-4k+4=0$ the discriminant is $(-4)^2-4(1)(4)=16-16=0$. This has exactly one solution, so we solve for $k$: \\[k=\\frac{4 \\pm \\sqrt{0}}{2} = 2.\\] For the second equation $k^2-4k+14=0$, the discriminant is $(-4)^2-4(1)(14)=16-56=-40$, which has no real solutions. Therefore, the value of $k$ is $\\boxed{2}$.
source_question: "There is only one value of $k$ for which the line $x=k$ intersects the graphs of $y=x^2+6x+5$ and $y=mx+b$ at two points which are exactly $5$ units apart. If the line $y=mx+b$ passes through the point $(1,6)$, and $b\neq 0$, find the equation of the line.  Enter your answer in the form "$y = mx + b$"."
output: "The line $x=k$ intersects $y=x^2+6x+5$ at the point $(k, k^2+6k+5)$ and the line $y=mx+b$ at the point $(k,mk+b)$. Since these two points have the same $x$-coordinate, the distance between them is the difference of their $y$-coordinates, so we have $$|(k^2+6k+5)-(mk+b)|=5.$$ Simplifying, this gives us two quadratic equations: $k^2+(6-m)k+5-b=5$ and $k^2+(6-m)k+5-b=-5$. We can express these as  \begin{align*}k^2+(6-m)k-b=0&\quad(1)\\k^2+(6-m)k+10-b=0.&\quad(2)\end{align*} We know that all solutions to both of these equations will be places where the line $y=mx+b$ is a vertical distance of $5$ from the parabola, but we know there can only be one such solution! Thus there must be exactly $1$ solution to one of the equations, and no solutions to the other equation. We find the discriminants ($b^2-4ac$) of the equations, so for equation $(1)$ the discriminant is $(6-m)^2-4(1)(-b)=(6-m)^2+4b$. For equation $(2)$ the discriminant is $(6-m)^2-4(1)(10-b)=(6-m)^2+4b-40$. One of these equations must equal zero, and one must be less than zero. Since $-40<0$, adding $(6-m)^2+4b$ to both sides doesn't change the inequality and $(6-m)^2+4b-40<(6-m)^2+4b$, so the greater value must be equal to zero so that the lesser value is always less than zero. Thus we have $(6-m)^2+4b=0$.We are also given that the line $y=mx+b$ passes through the point $(1,6)$, so substituting $x=1$ and $y=6$ gives $6=(1)m+b$ or $m+b=6$. This means that $6-m=b$, so we can substitute in the above equation: \begin{align*}(6-m)^2+4b&=0\quad\Rightarrow\\(b)^2+4b&=0\quad\Rightarrow\\b(b+4)&=0.\end{align*} We are given that $b\neq 0$, so the only solution is $b=-4$. When we plug this into the equation $m+b=6$, we find $m-4=6$ so $m=10$. Thus the equation of the line is $y=mx+b$ or $\boxed{y=10x-4}$."

reverse_problem: For what values of $(a, b)$ the following operation $a\\,\\spadesuit\\,b = |a- b|$ results in 1?
reverse_solution_process: Work from the inside out: \\[2\\,\\spadesuit\\,(4\\,\\spadesuit\\, 7)=2\\,\\spadesuit\\,(|4-7|) = 2\\,\\spadesuit\\,|-3| = 2\\,\\spadesuit\\, 3 = |2-3| = 1.\\] We will find all such pairs \\((a,b)\\) such that the operation $a\\,\\spadesuit\\,b = |a-b|$ yields 1. Substituting $|a - b| = 1$, the following integer pairs for \\((a,b)\\) satisfy this condition: \\(\\boxed{(a,b) = (2, 3), (3, 2)}\\).
source_question: "Define the operation $\spadesuit$ as $a\,\spadesuit\,b = |a- b|$ . What is the value of $2\, \spadesuit\,(4\,\spadesuit\,7)$?"

reverse_problem: Given an ordered pair $(u,v) = (-3,4)$, find the system of equations it solves.
reverse_solution_process: Substituting $u=-3$ and $v=4$ into the system of equations, we get: \\[\\begin{align*} 5(-3) &= -7 - 2(4), \\\\ 3(-3) &= 4(4) - 25. \\end{align*}\\] Simplifying, we have: \\[\\begin{align*} -15 &= -7 - 8, \\\\ -9 &= 16 - 25, \\end{align*}\\] which simplifies to the system: \\[\\begin{align*} 5u &= -7 - 2v, \\\\ 3u &= 4v - 25. \\end{align*}\\] Therefore, the system of equations it solves is \\[\\boxed{\\begin{align*} 5u &= -7 - 2v, \\\\ 3u &= 4v - 25. \\end{align*}}\\]
reverse_solution: The system of equations it solves is \\[\\boxed{\\begin{align*} 5u &= -7 - 2v, \\\\ 3u &= 4v - 25. \\end{align*}}\\]
source_question: "Find an ordered pair $(u,v)$ that solves the system: \begin{align*} 5u &= -7 - 2v,\\ 3u &= 4v - 25 \end{align*}"
output: "Multiplying the first equation by $2$ gives $10u = -14 - 4v$.  Adding this to the second equation gives $13u = -39$, so $ u= -3$.  Substituting this into $5u=-7-2v$ gives $-15=-7-2v$, so $v = 4$ and our solution is $(u,v) =\boxed{(-3,4)}$."
